title: 110_hr65
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians should be granted full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe, along with the benefits, privileges, and immunities that come with this status. The Lumbee Indians seek full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. Laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes will now apply to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Other Indian groups in North Carolina can petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for services after verifying a tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services and benefits, with the tribal roll defining the service population. The Secretary of the Interior will verify compliance with membership criteria within 2 years. Fee lands sought to be conveyed to the US must be within Robeson County, NC for trust acquisition. The tribe is prohibited from conducting gaming activities. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services and benefits, with the tribal roll defining the service population. The tribe is prohibited from conducting gaming activities and the State of North Carolina shall exercise jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on tribal lands. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to accept transfers of land from the State of North Carolina. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States as per an agreement with the State of North Carolina, with a 2-year waiting period. This transfer does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized for implementing this Act. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 7, 2007, as attested by Lorraine C. Miller, Clerk.
